sojo.net  (WEB - en-US)

The website of Sojourners, a liberal nonprofit that publishes a monthly print magazine by the same name, which covers Christianity, social justice, politics, and culture.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Sojo.net is owned by Sojourners, a Washington-based nonprofit. In addition to publishing Soujourners magazine, the organization regularly organizes cause-based activities, such as a campaign in 2017 seeking support for efforts to “protect and defend vulnerable people in the name of Jesus.” Sojourners also hosts an annual summit for leaders in faith and activism.

According to its 2017 financial statements, Sojourners brought in nearly $5 million in annual revenue, mostly from grants, donations, subscriptions, and advertising. A digital subscription is required to access the magazine’s full content online.

Content

Sojo.net covers Christianity, social justice, the environment, politics, and culture. The site’s news and commentaries sometimes address provocative topics such as “Is It Okay to Punch a Neo-Nazi?” and “American Christianity Has Become an Institution of Intolerance.”

Sojo.net publishes articles from the Soujourners monthly magazine, supplemented by original online content. Other articles are produced by third-party news providers including Reuters and the Medill News Service. Soujourners also produces podcasts, including “The Soul of the Nation” and “God Beat,” that can be streamed on the site.

Typical headlines on the site have included: “We Must Go Beyond Trump and Reconstruct Our Democracy,” “My Blackness Is Not At Odds With My Faith in Christ,” and “When White Nationalist Christians Redefined Their Neighbors.”

Credibility

Sojourners has a staff of approximately 40 who operate the organization and create most of its digital and print content, according to its online staff listing. The site’s contributing writers are often ministers, professors, or activists.

On its Who We Are page, Sojo.net describes its liberal agenda, stating: “The mission of Sojourners is to articulate the biblical call to social justice, to inspire hope and build a movement to transform individuals, communities, the church, and the world.” The site posts a diversity statement, which asserts the organization’s commitment to counter discrimination and promote equal rights.

Stories are clearly marked as either News or Commentary, with both relying on, and linking to, credible sources, including Pew Research Center studies and media outlets such as Bloomberg, ProPublica, and The News York Times. Commentary, which often discuss the intersection of faith and politics, sometimes includes Scripture passages.

Sojourners’ coverage is delivered with a liberal agenda, sometimes encouraging readers to express their faith through political activism. But because the site discloses its perspective and does not misstate or distort facts, NewsGuard has determined that it mixes opinion and news responsibly.

Sojo.net regularly issues corrections and updates to its articles, which are noted at the bottom of articles in italics.

Transparency

Sojo.net articles are published with author names, some of which are Sojourners staff and others are groups, such as the Auburn Senior Fellows, a group of 25 faith leaders. Articles written by Sojourners’ staff and freelance writers include links to brief biographies and contact information. Occasionally, author names say only, “By the Web Editors,” but most  stories identify their author, often providing biographical details at the bottom.

A Who We Are page includes a staff list that provides names and contact information for Sojourners management, writers, and editors.

Sojo.net indicates that it is owned by the nonprofit Sojourners in multiple places on the site, including on its Donate page and within articles. Sojo.net also posts recent, audited financial statements. However, the site does not identify any of its major donors -- which is why NewsGuard has determined that it does not meet the standard for nonprofits to disclose ownership and financing.

Sojourners did not respond to NewsGuard’s two emails seeking comment about its policy for disclosing donors.

Advertising is distinguished from editorial content.

History

Sojourners magazine, originally called The Post-American, was founded in 1971 by a Christian group called the Sojourners Community, according to the site’s About Us section. The community formed at Trinity Evangelical Divinity School in Deerfield, Illinois, and moved to Washington in 1975, when the magazine’s name was changed to Sojourners.

Sojourners’ founder and president of Sojourners, Rev. Jim Wallis, served on President Barack Obama’s Advisory Council on Faith-Based and Community Partnership. He also has served as a spiritual advisor to politicians, including Obama and U.S. Rep. Joseph Kennedy III.
